chapter.title: What we want to do
chapter.para: We would like to release OTHERobjects and the rest on our software stack (including OTHERcommerce and OTHERclicks) as open-source software. Other users will be able to download the software and use it to build websites.

The biggest danger facing an open-source project in irrelevance. By providing a high quality and complete Java based software stack we think we could get a fair sized community relatively quickly. Key to that though is releasing unique and useful software.

Whilst there are a few other open source Java CMS systems they lack polish. There are only a couple of open source Java eCommerce systems and they are not widely adopted. This presents us with an excellent opportunity to make a bit impact in the open-source java space.

chapter.title: Why we should do it
chapter.para: Open-sourcing a project effectively gives it away for free. It is this idea that makes many people uneasy about the idea of open-sourcing a project that has taken many years and many thousands of pounds to develop. This section outlines some of the benefits that come from having an open-source project.

section.title: Excellent publicity
section.para: This gives a real story to shout about. It will increase our profile in the industry and make potential clients aware of us.

section.title: Technical reputation
section.para: Currently we have no real technical reputation. By creating and championing an open source project we could gain a reputation as a very strong development shop. It puts us ahead of the curve -- no other agencies are doing this.

section.title: Feedback and ideas from external users
section.para: By making OO available for others to use we will receive feedback from them. They will bring new ideas and new ways of building sites that we won't have thought of.

section.title: Feedback from experienced programmers
section.para: There are almost certainly much better ways of doing some of the things we have done. As an open source project we would receive feedback and advice from other experienced programmers.

section.title: Our work done by external developers
section.para: Other users of OO will report problems and ask for new features. Some of them will fix the problems and build the features themselves, saving us time and effort. If other developers adopt OO seriously they may contribute significant amounts of useful code -- in effect sharing the development costs.

section.title: Feedback from associated projects
section.para: The other projects that we use in OTHERobjects (Hibernate, Velocity) have considerable experience integrating with projects like OTHERobjects. By making our code open source we can show them how we have approached the problem and get their feedback.

section.title: Better access to developers of associated projects
section.para: There are times when we would like changes made to associated projects. As an open source project we would stand a much better chance of having our opinions heard and acted on.

section.title: Incentive to write better code and documentation
section.para: Developing code with the knowledge that it will be seen by others encourages you to question, justify and document your decisions. The result is better, more secure and more maintainable code.

section.title: Vulnerabilities can be discovered, reported and fixed
section.para: Peer review is the standard methodology for security related projects. Other developers will be able to check our code and notify us of any security issues.

section.title: Better for education
section.para: If the code is open source it is much easier to use it in articles and lectures. Students or readers can download OO, see how it works and start using it. They could choose to base projects around it, providing us with another pool of developers.

section.title: Finding employees
section.para: Our standard no-thank-you letter to job applicants should contain an invitation to get involved with the OO project. Those who do get involved and produce good code could be employed at a later date. Good developers may also be drawn to us by OO project making it easier to recruit.

section.title: Finding freelancers
section.para: With a closed source CMS only our developers will know how to use it. Anyone who starts using our open-source CMS becomes a potential freelancer who can help us out during busy periods.

section.title: Higher profile for our developers
section.para: Designers have their work on constant display but developers work is hidden. Open source is an opportunity for the OTHER media to show off the quality of its technical team.

section.title: Reassure clients who are worried about lock-in
section.para: A common concern from larger clients is that they are locked in to our proprietary CMS. Using an open-source CMS (especially one with a growing user base) will alleviate these fears.

section.title: People who adopt OO become potential clients
section.para: Organisations who start using OO for their sites will eventually need new features for their sites. The natural supplier services to these companies will be the OTHER media.

section.title: Clients who understand open source will like us more
section.para: Those clients who understand open source (and that includes large corporations and governments) will know why we have chosen to open source our code and like us for it.

section.title: Clients who have technical knowledge will respect us more
section.para: Larger clients will have technical employees who will be able to see the scale and quality of what we have developed.

section.title: Access to commercial development tools at no cost
section.para: Several development tools vendors provide free licenses to open-source projects. Examples include Yourkit Profiler (which makes it easy to find performance bottlenecks), Clover (which measures how much of your code is excised in tests) and Fisheye (which provides detailed information about the source code repository). To purchase these tools would cost thousands of dollars.

section.title: It makes us more attractive to investors
section.para: Open source is a major part of many new companies. Being the owner of a widely used open source project makes us a much more interesting company to potential investors.

section.title: Give back some of what we're taking
section.para: OO wouldn't have be possible without open source. We are now completely dependent on other open source projects. Since we have gained so much from open source we have a moral duty to give back in some way.

chapter.title: Why we should think carefully about this
chapter.para: Some reasons against open-sourcing our software:

section.title: Explaining to clients why our software is free
section.para: We are already charging them for a lot of free stuff: Linux, Apache, Java, postgres, velocity, hibernate. OO would represent a tiny fraction of the free code we are using. And the majority of our clients are not paying for OO anyway.

section.title: Hackers can spot vulnerabilities in the code and exploit them
section.para: By making out code available developers can spot the weaknesses. Instead of reporting them they may choose to exploit them. However, the general consensus in the security community is that hackers will find the weaknesses anyway and that it is better to have the code open so that people can help find and fix the weakness. We should also consider a third-party security audit before the initial release.

section.title: Competing agencies may use OTHERobjects (and pitch against us)
section.para: If this is a concern we should always inform clients that we have an open source CMS that we have developed and that other agencies are free to use it. If we demo our system it will be pretty obvious if another company is using a rebranded version of our CMS. And in this situation we would have a considerable technical advantage as the creators not just the users of the CMS. A more likely scenario is that other agencies use our CMS for projects that we don't pitch for and develop new and useful plugins for us.

chapter.title: Licensing options
chapter.para: One of the most important factors influcencing the success of an open source project is the license chosen. It is the license that determines who will be able to use the project, for what purposes and under what restrictions.

section.title: License types
section.para: We can choose to either create a new license from scratch, modify and existing license or use a general purpose license. The Open Source Initiative keeps a list of approved open source licenses and it is important for both community-acceptance and marketing that whichever license we use is OSI approved. There was a brief fashion for "vanity" licenses where a company would take an exsting general purpose license, modify it slightly and the name it after themselves (for example the Mozilla Public License, Lucent Public License) but the needless proliferatino of these has caused the OSI to stop approving such licenses.
The most obvious choice is therefore to chose from one of the widely known and used general purpose licenses of which there are 2 main types:

section.title: Apache/BSD/MIT Licenses
section.para: “You are free to use this code however you want.”

This is arguably the most “open” open source projects. All the open source components included in OO5 are licensed under this type of license which allows us to resell OO without restrictions. A BSD licensed project can be used in any commercial project with no restrictions.

section.title: GNU Public License
section.para: “If you use this code in your project, then you must also open-source your project”

This license effectively prevents the code being used in commercial products. Whilst there in nothing in the license that specifically prevents the code being modified and sold as a product, if this does happen then the code of the commercial product would be required to be open source, thus allowing others to distribute it free of charge. As a consequence of this, any enhancements made by third parties to our code would need to be released publicly and we could incorporate them into future versions.

section.title: Future licensing options
section.para: As the copyright holder (see next section) to all the code we would have the option of changing the licensing policy at some point in the future time. For example, we could offer an unrestricted commercial license that would allow other companies to use our code in their projects. We would also have the right to stop releasing OO as open-source. However, past releases would always remain open. We should also be aware that any license changes may upset any community that grows around the project.

chapter.title: Copyright and trademark issues
chapter.para: We recommend that the copyright to all the code in OTHERobjects is owned by the OTHER media (or OTHERworks?). All contributors to the code base would be asked to assign the copyright of their code over to the OTHER media.

The trademarks for the name (and logos) for OTHERobjects would continue to be held by the OTHER media. We would have the right to restrict their usage if we so wished. See http://www.ubuntu.com/aboutus/trademarkpolicy for an example of how another project does this.

chapter.title: The Process
chapter.para: Releasing and running a successfull open-source project will require some addition work. A rough overview of the process is described here.

section.title: Legal preparation
section.para: The first step is to choose a license (we recommend GPLv2) and the copyright holder (either OTHERmedia or OTHERworks).
We should check that any name and artwork we wish to protect are appropriately trademarked.

section.title: Naming decisions
section.para: The natural name for our new version of OTHERobjects is OTHERobjects 6.0. However, the open-source world tends to be slightly suspicisous of mature proprietary projects becoming open-source. We should be releasing a version 1.0 project that can grow with the community.
We also need to carefully consider how other projects will be named. What is the overall brand. OTHERworks? OTHERobjects?

section.title: Code review
section.para: We need to check that:

listitem.para: We are the copyright holder of all the code and have the right to release it
The files contain appropriate copyright and license information
The tests are complete and have good coverage

section.para: There are tools to help with this task and we estimate that it will take approximately 2 weeks.

section.title: Documentation
section.para: A major stumbling block in the adoption of open source projects is the lack of quality documentation. We intend to publish 4 manuals to accompany the first release of OTHERobjects:

listitem.para: User Guide (for users of the CMS such as our clients)
Site Builder Guide (for advanced users to build and extend their site without using Java)
Dveloper Guide (for developers looking to build advnced sites, write plugins or work on OTHERobjects)
Hosting Guide (for administrators hosting in more complex setups than the default embedded mode)

section.para: This documentatino is in progress and will probably require 4-6 weeks more work.

section.title: Ongoing community support
section.para: Community support involves:

listitem.para: Monitoring forums and mailing lists and bug reports
Responding to reporting on other sites

section.para: It is hard to tell how much time this may take and will largely depend on the size of the community that grows around otherobjects. A good first estimate would be about one day per week.

section.title: Marketing
section.para: A larger community creates a larger pool of people able to improve OTHERobjects. Once the project is somewhat established and initial feedback has been taken into account we should start to market our project more widely.
This may take 1-2 days a month.

chapter.title: Conclusions
chapter.para: The open-sourcing of OTHERobjects will likely be the most significant event for the OTHER media in 2008. It has the potential to change the way we both work and think as a company and hopefully we will soon start to see the benefits.
